title: The works of Robert Louis Stevenson;
author: Stevenson, Robert Louis
snippet: Half an hour later, Sir Daniel gave Dick the letter, and bade him speed to the Moat House. And again, some half an hour after Dick's departure, a messenger came, in hot haste, from my Lord of Risingham.

title: The novels and tales of Robert Louis Stevenson.

snippet: Half an hour later, Sir Daniel gave Dick the letter, and bade him speed to the Moat House. And, again, some half an hour after Dick's departure, a messenger came, in hot haste, from my Lord of Risingham.

title: The novels and tales of Robert Louis Stevenson.
author: Stevenson, Robert Louis
snippet: A score or so of houses, heavily framed with oak, stood scattered in a long green valley ascending from the river. At the foot, the road crossed a bridge, and mounting on the other side, disappeared into the fringes of the forest on its way to the Moat House, and further forth to Holywood Abbey. Half-way up the village, the church stood among yews.

title: The novels and tales of Robert Louis Stevenson.
author: Stevenson, Robert Louis
snippet: THE Moat House stood not far from the rough forest road. Externally, it was a compact rectangle of red stone, flanked at each corner by a round tower, pierced for archery and battlemented at the top.

title: The works of Robert Louis Stevenson;
author: Stevenson, Robert Louis
snippet: " Friend Dick," he said, as soon as they were alone, " are ye a moonstruck natural.? An ye leave not certain things in peace, ye were better in the salt sea than here in Tunstall Moat House. Y' have questioned me ; y' have baited Carter ; y' have frighted the jack-priest with hints.

title: The novels and tales of Robert Louis Stevenson.
author: Stevenson, Robert Louis
snippet: Where be all my good men-at-arms ? Dick, by the mass, I know not! We were swept down; the shot fell thick among us; I have not seen one man in my own colours since I saw three fall. For myself, I came sound to Shoreby, and being mindful of the Black Arrow, got me this gown and bell, and came softly by the path for the Moat House. snippet: " An ye win safe to the Moat House, y' have done lucky; but I say no more." And then catching sight of Matcham, "Who be this?" he asked, as he paused, blinking, on the threshold of his cabin.

snippet: He smiled at the remembrance of his strange companion, and then wondered where he was. Ever since they had come together to the doors of the ^Moat House the younger lad had disappeared, and Dick began to weary for a word with him.

title: The works of Robert Louis Stevenson;
author: Stevenson, Robert Louis
snippet: For a few steps missiles followed him, but these soon ceased; and when at length he came to a halt and looked behind, he was already a good way from the Moat House, though he could still see the torches moving to and fro along its battlements.

title: The works of Robert Louis Stevenson;

snippet: Dick, by the mass, I know not! We were swept down; the shot fell thick among us; I have not seen one man in m}"- own colours since I saw three fall. For myself, I came sound to Shoreby, and being mindful of the Black Arrow, got me this gown and bell, and came softly by the path for the Moat House. There is no disguise to be compared with it; the jingle of this bell would scare me the stoutest outlaw in the forest; they would all turn pale to hear it.

title: The works of Robert Louis Stevenson;

title: The works of Robert Louis Stevenson;
author: Stevenson, Robert Louis
snippet: T was almost certain that Sir Daniel had made for the Moat House ; but, considering the heavy snow, the lateness  of the hour, and the necessity under which he would lie of avoiding the few roads and striking across the wood, it was equally certain that he could not hope to reach it ere the morrow.

title: The works of Robert Louis Stevenson;
author: Stevenson, Robert Louis
snippet: " A wilful man ! " returned the ferryman, rising. " An ye win safe to the Moat House, y' have done lucky ; but I say no more." And then catching sight of Matcham, " Who be this.'*" he asked, as he passed, blinking, on the threshold of his cabin.

title: The works of Robert Louis Stevenson;
author: Stevenson, Robert Louis
snippet: " It befell between the Moat House and Holywood," replied  Sir Daniel, calmly ; but he shot a covert glance, black with suspicion, at Dick's face. " And now," added the knight, " speed you with your meal ; ye shall retura to Tunstall  with a line from me."

title: The works of Robert Louis Stevenson;
author: Stevenson, Robert Louis
snippet: Hatch and Sir Oliver discussed together for awhile their altered situation ; ten men, it was decided between them, should be reserved, not only to garrison the Moat House, but to escort the priest across the wood. In the meantime, as Bennet was to remain behind, the command of the reinforcement  was given to Master Shelton.

title: The works of Robert Louis Stevenson;

title: The novels and tales of Robert Louis Stevenson.
author: Stevenson, Robert Louis
snippet: ON a certain afternoon, in the late springtime, the bell upon Tunstall Moat House was heard ringing at an unaccustomed hour. Far and near, in the forest and in the fields along the river, people began to desert their labours and hurry towards the sound ; and in Tunstall  hamlet a group of poor country-folk stood wondering  at the summons.

title: The novels and tales of Robert Louis Stevenson.

title: The works of Robert Louis Stevenson;

snippet: ON a certain afternoon, in the late springtime, the bell upon Tunstall Moat House was heard ringing at an unaccustomed hour. Far and near, in the forest and in the fields along the river, people began to desert their labours and hurry towards the sound ; and in Tunstall hamlet a group of poor country-folk stood wondering at the summons.

title: The novels and tales of Robert Louis Stevenson.
author: Stevenson, Robert Louis
snippet: IT was almost certain that Sir Daniel had made for the Moat House; but, considering the heavy snow, the lateness  of the hour, and the necessity under which he would lie of avoiding the few roads and striking across the wood, it was equally certain that he could not hope to reach it ere the morrow.

title: The works of Robert Louis Stevenson;
author: Stevenson, Robert Louis
snippet: All that time he had seen no more of Sir Oliver, and nothing of Matcham ; and yet both the priest and the young lad ran continually in his mind. It was now his chief purpose to escape from Tunstall Moat House as speedily as might be ; and yet, before he went, he desired a word with both of these.

title: The novels and tales of Robert Louis Stevenson.
author: Stevenson, Robert Louis
snippet: Over the thunderstorm of blows the cry of a sentinel was heard; it was followed by another; shouts ran along the battlements, shouts answered out of the wood. In the first moment of alarm it sounded as if the foresters were carrying the Moat House by assault. And Sir Daniel and his men, desisting instantly from their attack upon Dick's chamber, hurried to defend the walls.

title: The novels and tales of Robert Louis Stevenson.
author: Stevenson, Robert Louis
snippet: Dick breathed deep, and then, and not till then, he gave ear to the disturbance  which had interrupted the attack, and which was now rather increasing than diminishing. All about the Moat House feet were running, doors were opening and slamming, and still the voice of Sir Daniel towered above all this bustle, shouting for "Joanna."

title: The novels and tales of Robert Louis Stevenson.
author: Stevenson, Robert Louis
snippet: "Friend Dick," he said, as soon as they were alone, "are ye a moon-struck natural ? An ye leave not certain  things in peace, ye were better in the salt sea than here in Tunstall Moat House. Y' have questioned me; y' have baited Carter; y' have frighted the jack-priest with hints.

title: The novels and tales of Robert Louis Stevenson.
author: Stevenson, Robert Louis
snippet: But now there came an interruption. From a distant corner of the Moat House shouts began to be heard, and first one voice, and then several, crying aloud upon a name. This noise had plainly disconcerted the murderer,  for the trap-door was silently lowered to its place, and the steps hurriedly returned, passed once more close below the lads, and died away in the distance.

title: The novels and tales of Robert Louis Stevenson.
author: Stevenson, Robert Louis
snippet: He smiled at the remembrance of his strange companion, and then wondered  where he was. Ever since they had come together to the doors of the Moat House the younger lad had disappeared,  and Dick began to weary for a word with him.

title: The novels and tales of Robert Louis Stevenson.
author: Stevenson, Robert Louis
snippet: Twelve of Sir Daniel's party had escaped the battle, run the gauntlet through the wood, and come alive to the Moat House. But out of this dozen, three had been gravely wounded : two at Risingham in the disorder of the rout, one by John Amend-AH's marksmen as he crossed the forest.

title: The works of Robert Louis Stevenson;

snippet: A score or so of houses, heavily framed with oak, stood scattered  in a long green valley ascending from the river. Half-way up the village, the church stood among yews.

title: The works of Robert Louis Stevenson;
author: Stevenson, Robert Louis
snippet: A little later in the day, and after Dick had awakened from a comfortable slumber to find himself still very weak, but clearer in mind and easier in body, Ellis returned, and sitting down by the bedside, begged him, in the nam.e of his father, to relate the circumstance of his escape from Tunstall Moat House. There was something in the strength of Duckworth's frame, in the honesty of his brown face, in the clearness and shrewdness of his e3'es, that moved Dick to obey him ; and from first to last the lad told him the story of his two days' adventures.

title: The works of Robert Louis Stevenson;

snippet: Over the thunderstorm of blows the cry of a sentinel was heard; it was followed by another ; shouts ran along the battlements,  shouts answered out of the wood. In the first moment of alarm it sounded as if the foresters were carrying the Moat House by assault. And Sir Daniel and his men, desisting  instantly from their attack upon Dick's chamber, hurried to defend the walls.

title: The works of Robert Louis Stevenson;

This noise had plainly disconcerted the murderer, for the trap-door was silently lowered to its place, and the steps hurriedly returned, passed once more close below the lads, and ched away in the distance.

title: The works of Robert Louis Stevenson;

snippet: " Eat ! " he cried, suddenly. " And you here," he added to Matcham, " swear me an oath to follow straight to the Moat House."

snippet: " Lawless," replied the other, " to reach the Moat House, Sir Daniel must pass the forest. We shall make that passage  dearer, pardy, than any battle.

title: The works of Robert Louis Stevenson;

snippet: " Nick Appleyard," said Hatch, " Sir Oliver commends him to you, and bids that ye shall come within this hour to the Moat House, there to take command."

title: The works of Robert Louis Stevenson;
author: Stevenson, Robert Louis
snippet: Hard by the bridge, there was a stone cross upon a knoll, and here the group had collected — half a dozen women and one tall fellow in a russet smock — discussing what the bell betidcd. An express had gone through the hamlet half an hour before, and drunk a pot of ale in the saddle, not daring to dismount for the hurry of his errand ; but he had been ignorant himself of what was forward, and only bore sealed letters from Sir Daniel Brackley to Sir Oliver Oates, the parson,  who kept the Moat House in the master's absence.

title: The novels and tales of Robert Louis Stevenson.

There was something  in the strength of Duckworth's frame, in the honesty  of his brown face, in the clearness and shrewdness of his eyes, that moved Dick to obey him; and from first to last the lad told him the story of his two days' adventures.
